# Edge label text display (2026-02-03 07:45Z)

_**User**_

For the edge labels, instead of putting the text of (concatenated) and (injected) into the edge label, can you make this float under the existing label?

So that if I want to edit the edge label, I won't be accidentally editing this text, it would be in a separate floating container.

---

_**Agent (model default, mode Agent)**_

---


Summary of changes:

### 1. **Edge label no longer stores "(injected)" / "(concatenated)"**
- **`src/engine/runner.ts`**: After a run, the persisted edge label is only the variable name (e.g. `summary`). The suffix is no longer written to `edge.label`, so editing the edge label only changes the variable name.
- **`src/engine/state.ts`**: New in-memory state for edge mode: `getEdgeMode(canvasKey, edgeId)` and `setEdgeModes(canvasKey, modes)`. `clearCanvasState` also clears this edge-mode state.

### 2. **Floating "(injected)" / "(concatenated)" under the edge**
- **`src/canvas/canvasNodeLabels.ts`**:
  - `clearCanvasEdgeModeLabels(containerEl)` removes our overlay labels.
  - `syncCanvasEdgeModeLabels(vault, canvasFilePath, containerEl, canvas)`:
    - Loads canvas data and, for each edge with a mode in state, finds the from/to node elements.
    - Computes the edge midpoint in container coordinates.
    - Creates a small div with `(injected)` or `(concatenated)`, positioned at that point (with a 4px offset below), and appends it to the canvas container.
- **`src/main.ts`**: Same place that syncs node role labels now also calls `syncCanvasEdgeModeLabels` and clears edge mode labels when leaving the canvas (and on the 2s interval so positions stay correct when panning/zooming).

### 3. **Styling**
- **`styles.css`**: New `.ztb-edge-mode-label`: non-interactive, smaller muted text, so it reads as a hint under the edge and not as part of the editable label.

Result:
- The **editable** edge label is only the variable name (e.g. `summary`).
- **(injected)** or **(concatenated)** is shown in a **separate floating div** near the edge midpoint, so you can edit the edge label without touching that text.

---

_**User**_

Can you make the floating edge label lower and smaller?

Give me five suggestions to show that. A node is currently running (waiting for response from AI) and even that the information is passing from that edge (turn it into a different color depend on 'not run', 'injected' and 'concatenated')

---

_**Agent (model default, mode Agent)**_

{
  "plan": "# Edge label: lower/smaller + five suggestions for state colors (not run, injected, concatenated, running)\n\n## Current behavior\n\n- Floating edge labels are rendered in [src/canvas/canvasNodeLabels.ts](src/canvas/canvasNodeLabels.ts) (&#96;syncCanvasEdgeModeLabels&#96;): only edges with a mode in state get a div with \"(injected)\" or \"(concatenated)\" at the edge midpoint, with &#96;marginTop: 4px&#96;, class &#96;.ztb-edge-mode-label&#96; (in [styles.css](styles.css): &#96;font-size: var(--font-smaller)&#96;, &#96;color: var(--text-muted)&#96;).\n- There is no \"node is running\" state; [src/engine/runner.ts](src/engine/runner.ts) runs nodes async but does not expose which node is currently running.\n\n## 1. Lower and smaller (all options)\n\n- **CSS**: Reduce font size (e.g. &#96;var(--font-smaller)&#96; plus &#96;transform: scale(0.85)&#96; or a new smaller size), increase vertical offset so the label sits lower under the edge (e.g. &#96;marginTop&#96; from 4px to 8–10px in JS, or a CSS margin).\n- **Code**: In &#96;syncCanvasEdgeModeLabels&#96;, increase the offset used for &#96;label.style.marginTop&#96; (e.g. to 8px or 10px). In [styles.css](styles.css), make &#96;.ztb-edge-mode-label&#96; smaller (e.g. &#96;font-size: 0.75em&#96; or use a scale).\n\n## 2. Running state (needed for “running” color)\n\n- **State** in [src/engine/state.ts](src/engine/state.ts): Add &#96;runningNodeId: Map&lt;canvasKey, string | null&gt;&#96; (or one &#96;canvasKey -&gt; nodeId | null&#96;) with &#96;setRunningNodeId(canvasKey, nodeId | null)&#96; and &#96;getRunningNodeId(canvasKey)&#96;.\n- **Runner** in [src/engine/runner.ts](src/engine/runner.ts): Before &#96;runSingleNode&#96; (and each iteration in runChain), call &#96;setRunningNodeId(canvasKey, nodeId)&#96;; when the run finishes (success or catch), call &#96;setRunningNodeId(canvasKey, null)&#96;.\n- **Edge overlay**: When building the floating label for an edge, if &#96;toNode === getRunningNodeId(canvasKey)&#96; then treat that edge as \"running\" (data passing into the node that is currently running).\n\n## 3. Four states and colors\n\n- **Not run**: Edge has no mode in state and is not an incoming edge to the currently running node.\n- **Injected**: Edge has mode &#96;\"inject\"&#96; in state.\n- **Concatenated**: Edge has mode &#96;\"concatenate\"&#96; in state.\n- **Running**: Edge is an incoming edge to the node that is currently running (toNode === runningNodeId).\n\nUse theme-friendly colors (CSS variables), e.g.:\n\n- Not run: &#96;var(--text-faint)&#96; or &#96;var(--text-muted)&#96;.\n- Injected: e.g. &#96;var(--color-blue)&#96; or a blue accent if available; fallback a muted blue.\n- Concatenated: e.g. green accent.\n- Running: e.g. orange/amber and optional subtle pulse animation.\n\n## 4. Five suggestions (pick one to implement)\n\n**Suggestion A — Text color only**  \nLower/smaller label; color the text by state. For \"not run\" we only show a label for edges that have a mode; optionally show a minimal label (e.g. \"—\") for not-run edges. No extra DOM. Easiest.\n\n**Suggestion B — Pill/badge with background**  \nSame position/size; wrap text in a small pill (padding + border-radius). Background color by state (grey / blue / green / orange). Running = orange pill + optional pulse. Most visible.\n\n**Suggestion C — Accent bar (left border or dot)**  \nLower/smaller label; add a 2–3px left border or a small colored dot (e.g. &#96;::before&#96;) on the floating div. Color the bar/dot by state; text can stay muted or match. Clean and compact.\n\n**Suggestion D — Icon + text**  \nLower/smaller; prepend a small colored circle or dot (e.g. &#96;::before&#96; or a span) next to the text, colored by state. Running shows \"…\" or a small spinner (CSS animation). Good for quick scanning.\n\n**Suggestion E — Show all edges with a minimal dot**  \nEvery non-output edge gets a tiny floating element: not run = small grey dot or \"—\"; injected = blue \"(injected)\"; concatenated = green \"(concatenated)\"; running = orange pulsing dot/label. No \"empty\" edges; full graph state at a glance. Slightly more DOM and logic (show label for every non-output edge).\n\n## 5. Implementation outline (once one suggestion is chosen)\n\n- **State**: Add running-node get/set/clear in [src/engine/state.ts](src/engine/state.ts); clear on &#96;clearCanvasState&#96; if desired.\n- **Runner**: Set/clear running node around &#96;runSingleNode&#96; (and in the loop in &#96;runChain&#96;) in [src/engine/runner.ts](src/engine/runner.ts).\n- **Canvas labels**: In &#96;syncCanvasEdgeModeLabels&#96; (and possibly for \"not run\" in Suggestion E), for each relevant edge compute state: running if &#96;edge.toNode === getRunningNodeId(canvasKey)&#96;, else inject/concatenate from &#96;getEdgeMode&#96;, else \"not run\". Apply a data attribute or class (e.g. &#96;data-ztb-edge-state=\"running\"|\"inject\"|\"concatenate\"|\"not-run\"&#96;) and optionally different copy (\"(injected)\", \"(concatenated)\", \"—\", \"…\" for running).\n- **CSS**: In [styles.css](styles.css): (1) make &#96;.ztb-edge-mode-label&#96; lower and smaller; (2) add rules for &#96;[data-ztb-edge-state=\"inject\"]&#96;, &#96;[data-ztb-edge-state=\"concatenate\"]&#96;, &#96;[data-ztb-edge-state=\"running\"]&#96;, &#96;[data-ztb-edge-state=\"not-run\"]&#96; (color and, for B/C/D/E, pill, bar, icon, or dot). If \"running\" uses a pulse, add a small &#96;@keyframes&#96; pulse for opacity or color.\n- **Optional**: For Suggestion E, change the loop so we create a floating element for every non-output edge (not only those with a mode), with state derived as above.\n\n## Summary\n\n- **Guaranteed**: Lower and smaller floating label + four states (not run, injected, concatenated, running) with distinct colors and running state tracked in the engine.\n- **Choice**: Implement one of the five suggestions (A–E) for how that state is shown (text only, pill, accent bar, icon+text, or minimal dot on every edge).\n",

---


Summary of what was implemented for **Suggestion D — Icon + text**:

### 1. **Running state** ([src/engine/state.ts](src/engine/state.ts))
- `runningNodeState`: map of canvas key → node id (or null).
- `getRunningNodeId(canvasKey)` and `setRunningNodeId(canvasKey, nodeId | null)`.
- `clearCanvasState` also clears the running node for that canvas.

### 2. **Runner** ([src/engine/runner.ts](src/engine/runner.ts))
- **Run node**: `setRunningNodeId(canvasKey, nodeId)` before `runSingleNode`, and `setRunningNodeId(canvasKey, null)` in a `finally` block.
- **Run chain**: for each node, set running node before `runSingleNode` and clear it in a `finally` after each node.

### 3. **Edge overlay — icon + text** ([src/canvas/canvasNodeLabels.ts](src/canvas/canvasNodeLabels.ts))
- **Display state** per edge: `running` (incoming to the running node), `inject`, or `concatenate` (from existing edge mode).
- A floating label is shown only for edges that are either incoming to the running node or have a stored mode.
- Each label is a wrapper `div` with:
  - `data-ztb-edge-state="running"|"inject"|"concatenate"`.
  - A **dot icon** (`span.ztb-edge-mode-icon`).
  - **Text**: `…` for running, `(injected)` for inject, `(concatenated)` for concatenate.
- Label is placed **lower**: `marginTop` increased from 4px to 10px.

### 4. **CSS** ([styles.css](styles.css))
- **Label**: smaller (`font-size: 0.7em`), `inline-flex` with a small gap between icon and text.
- **Icon**: 5×5px circle (`.ztb-edge-mode-icon`).
- **Colors by state** (with fallbacks):
  - **Injected**: blue dot + blue text (`var(--color-blue, #3b82f6)`).
  - **Concatenated**: green dot + green text (`var(--color-green, #22c55e)`).
  - **Running**: orange dot + orange text (`var(--color-orange, #e68619)`) and a **pulse** animation on the dot (`ztb-edge-running-pulse`: opacity 1 ↔ 0.4 over 1s, repeated).

When a node is running, its **incoming** edges show an orange pulsing dot and “…”; after the run, they revert to the usual blue/green icon + “(injected)” or “(concatenated)” based on how that edge was used.

---

_**User**_

There is a weird bug with the smaller edge labels where if I drag around the canvas, their position does not stick to the current edge label.

Can you check the code base and look for other performance and logic problems like this? Issues which would affect the ease of use and make the canvas appear to be buggy.

---


Summary of what was fixed and hardened:

### 1. **Edge labels drifting when panning (main bug)**

**Cause:** Edge mode labels were absolutely positioned in the **view container** and never re-synced on pan/zoom. The canvas content (and nodes) moves with pan; the labels stayed in container coordinates, so they no longer lined up with edges.

**Change:** Labels are now attached to the **source node** of each edge (`fromEl`) and positioned relative to that node’s bounding rect:

- Midpoint is still computed in viewport space from the two node centers.
- We then convert to **offset from the source node**: `left = midViewportX - fromRect.left`, `top = midViewportY - fromRect.top + 10`.
- We **append the label to `fromEl`** instead of `containerEl`.

Because the label is a child of the node, it moves with the node when the canvas is panned or zoomed, so it stays on the edge.

**Code:** [src/canvas/canvasNodeLabels.ts](src/canvas/canvasNodeLabels.ts) — in `syncCanvasEdgeModeLabels`, positioning now uses `fromRect` and `fromEl.appendChild(label)`.

### 2. **Stale canvas after quick tab switch**

**Cause:** Sync is async (`loadCanvasData` then DOM updates). If the user switched to another canvas before the async part finished, we could still apply labels to the **previous** canvas’s container.

**Change:** Optional **“is still active”** check after the async load:

- `syncCanvasRoleLabels` and `syncCanvasEdgeModeLabels` accept an optional `isStillActive?: () => boolean`.
- It’s called **after** `await loadCanvasData(...)`. If it returns false, we return without changing the DOM.
- In `main.ts`, we pass `isStillActive: () => this.getActiveCanvasView()?.containerEl === roleLabelsContainerEl` so we only apply when this container is still the active canvas view.

This avoids painting labels onto a canvas that’s no longer visible and reduces pointless work.

**Code:** [src/canvas/canvasNodeLabels.ts](src/canvas/canvasNodeLabels.ts) (sync signatures and post-load check), [src/main.ts](src/main.ts) (passing `isStillActive` on initial sync and in the 2s interval).

### 3. **Other checks**

- **Clear still works:** `clearCanvasEdgeModeLabels(containerEl)` uses `containerEl.querySelectorAll(.ztb-edge-mode-label)`, which finds labels anywhere under the container, including inside nodes, so clearing is unchanged.
- **Interval (2s):** Still used for running-state and mode changes; no need to re-sync on every pan because labels now move with the nodes.
- **No change to node role labels:** They were already appended to `nodeEl`, so they already moved with the canvas; only edge labels needed the fix.

Build and tests pass; no new linter issues. If a canvas node uses `overflow: hidden`, an edge label near the node boundary could be clipped; that would require a different attachment strategy (e.g. a canvas-level overlay) if it shows up in practice.

---

_**User**_

The edge label should be position in the middle of the arrow under the exiting edge label so in the middle of <path class="canvas-display-path" d="M-340 -170 L-333 -170 M-333,-170 C-183,-170 -157,-650 -7,-650"></path>

Tell me what information you need to position this properly.

---

_**Agent (model default, mode Agent)**_


To position the floating edge label on the arrow and under the existing edge label, we need a few concrete details about how Obsidian draws the canvas. Here’s what’s needed and how you can get it.

### 1. **How to find the DOM element for a given edge**

- Is there a **single SVG** that contains all edge paths (and maybe edge labels)?
- For each edge, does any element have a **stable attribute we can match** to our edge id (e.g. `data-edge-id`, `data-from-node`/`data-to-node`, or an id that encodes the edge)?
- Or are edges rendered in a different way (e.g. one group per edge with a known structure)?

We need a reliable way to go from “edge id (or fromNode + toNode)” to the corresponding path (and ideally to the existing edge label element).

### 2. **Structure of the path and the “existing edge label”**

- You mentioned a path like:  
  `<path class="canvas-display-path" d="M-340 -170 L-333 -170 ...">`
- Is the **existing edge label** (the one the user can edit) a **sibling** of this path (e.g. inside the same `<g>` or group), or elsewhere?
- If it’s in the same group, what is the **tag and class** of that label element (e.g. `<text class="...">` or `<foreignObject>`)?

That tells us whether we can “put our label under the existing edge label” by attaching to the same group and using the same coordinate system.

### 3. **Coordinate system and transforms**

- Is the SVG (or its parent) **transformed** (e.g. `transform: translate(...) scale(...)`) for pan/zoom?
- When we get a point on the path (e.g. via `path.getPointAtLength(len/2)`), that point is in the **SVG’s coordinate system**. We need to know:
  - Whether we should **append our label inside that SVG** (e.g. as a `<text>` or `<foreignObject>`) so it automatically moves with the canvas, or
  - Whether we must **convert that point to viewport** and position an HTML overlay (and if so, which element’s client rect / transform to use).

### 4. **Ways to get this information**

If you can inspect the canvas in DevTools, these are the most useful:

1. **Edge path**
   - Select one edge (or its path) and note:
     - The **path** element’s classes, parent elements, and any `data-*` or `id`.
     - Whether it’s inside an SVG and what the SVG’s `transform` (or parent’s) is.
2. **Existing edge label**
   - Find the **editable edge label** for that same edge:
     - Tag (e.g. `<text>`, `<foreignObject>`, or a `<div>`).
     - Class names and parent (same `<g>` as the path or not).
3. **Linking path to our edge**
   - Check if the path (or its parent) has something like:
     - `data-edge-id="..."`,
     - or `data-from="nodeId"` / `data-to="nodeId"`,
     - or an `id` we can relate to our edge id.

If you can paste (or describe):

- The **HTML snippet** for one edge: the path + its parent(s) + the existing label element,
- And whether the path (or its group) has any **data attributes / id** that we can match to our edge id or fromNode/toNode,

then we can say exactly how to:
- Find the path for each of our edges,
- Compute the midpoint of the path (e.g. `getTotalLength()` and `getPointAtLength(totalLength/2)`),
- Either place our label in the middle of the arrow under the existing edge label in that same coordinate system, or convert that point to the right place for an overlay.

Implementing path-midpoint positioning: finding each edge's `path.canvas-display-path`, computing its midpoint, and inserting our label via a `foreignObject` in the same `g` so it stays in sync with the canvas transform.


---

Summary of changes:

### 1. **Position from the edge path**
- **`getPathMidpoint(pathEl)`** uses `pathEl.getTotalLength()` and `pathEl.getPointAtLength(length/2)` to get the midpoint of the visible edge path (`path.canvas-display-path`) in SVG coordinates.
- **`getEdgeGroupsInOrder(containerEl)`** collects all `path.canvas-display-path` elements, maps each to its parent `<g>`, and returns those groups in DOM order so they align with `data.edges` by index.

### 2. **Label in the same `<g>` as the path**
- For each edge that should show a label, we take the matching `<g>` and its `path.canvas-display-path`, compute the path midpoint, then create an SVG **`foreignObject`** at:
  - **x**: `mid.x - FO_WIDTH/2` (centered on the path)
  - **y**: `mid.y + Y_OFFSET_BELOW_PATH` (12px below the path so it sits under the line/arrow).
- The existing label div (icon + “(injected)” / “(concatenated)” / “…”) is appended inside this `foreignObject`, and the `foreignObject` is appended to the edge’s `<g>`.
- Because the label lives inside the same transformed SVG as the path, it stays on the arrow when you pan/zoom.

### 3. **Clear**
- **`clearCanvasEdgeModeLabels`** now removes elements with class `ztb-edge-mode-foreign` (the `foreignObject` wrappers) and still removes any legacy `.ztb-edge-mode-label` nodes.

### Constants
- **FO_WIDTH** = 100, **FO_HEIGHT** = 24, **Y_OFFSET_BELOW_PATH** = 12. You can tweak these in [src/canvas/canvasNodeLabels.ts](src/canvas/canvasNodeLabels.ts) if you want the label closer/further or a different box size.

**Assumption:** The order of `<g>` elements (by DOM order of `path.canvas-display-path`) matches the order of `data.edges`. If Obsidian ever reorders or filters edges in the DOM, we’d need a more stable way to map edge id → `<g>` (e.g. data attributes).

Stating hypotheses and adding instrumentation.

Hypotheses:
- A: Path midpoint is in negative SVG coords; FO's left edge (mid.x - 50) is outside the SVG/clip region, so the left side is clipped.
- B: The inner div's `transform: translate(-50%, 0)` shifts content left; the FO or SVG clips overflow so the left part of the content is cut off.
- C: FO width (100px) is too small and the label overflows; "cut off in front" is the visible part of that overflow/clipping.
- D: The `<g>` or SVG has overflow/clip so the FO (which extends 50px left of the path) is clipped at the group/SVG boundary.
- E: The `<g>` has a transform so our (mid.x, mid.y) is in the wrong coordinate system and the FO is misplaced and partially clipped.

Adding instrumentation to log mid point, FO position/size, and getBoundingClientRect after append.

Instrumentation is in place. Summary:

**Hypotheses we’re testing**

1. **A** – Path midpoint is in negative SVG coords; the foreignObject’s left edge (mid.x − 50) is outside the visible/clip area, so the left side is clipped.
2. **B** – The inner div’s `transform: translate(-50%, 0)` shifts content left so it overflows the foreignObject and gets clipped.
3. **C** – The foreignObject is too narrow for the label, so the text is clipped (overflow).
4. **D** – The `<g>` or SVG clips its contents, so the part of the FO that extends left of the path midpoint is cut off.
5. **E** – The `<g>` has a transform, so our coordinates are in the wrong space and the FO is partially off-screen.

**What was added**

- **Path midpoint / FO position**: For each edge we log `midX`, `midY`, `foX` (= mid.x − 50), `foY`, `foWidth`, `foHeight` (hypothesis A, E).
- **After append**: We log the foreignObject’s and the group’s `getBoundingClientRect()`, plus the label div’s width and left, and booleans: `foExtendsLeftOfGroup`, `labelExtendsLeftOfFO` (hypotheses B, C, D).

<reproduction_steps>
1. Rebuild the plugin if needed (`npm run build` or keep `npm run dev` running).
2. Restart or reload Obsidian so the updated plugin is loaded.
3. Open a canvas that has at least one edge with an edge status label (e.g. “(injected)” or “(concatenated)”) visible.
4. Confirm the label is partly cut off on the front (left) side.
5. Trigger a sync of the labels (e.g. switch to another leaf and back to the canvas, or wait for the next interval) so the new logging runs.
6. Click **Proceed** when done.
</reproduction_steps>

After you run these steps, I’ll read the log file and tell you which hypothesis is supported (and what to change in code/CSS).

---


Summary of what was changed:

### 1. **Reverted to “correct edge” via fromNode / toNode**
- Stopped using SVG path index. The label is no longer placed by matching `data.edges[i]` to the i-th `path.canvas-display-path` group.
- Placement is back to **this edge’s** `fromNode` and `toNode`: we resolve `fromEl` and `toEl` for that edge, compute the midpoint between them, and append the label to **fromEl** with `position: absolute` and coordinates relative to the source node.
- The status label is always under the right edge and still moves with the canvas when panning/zooming because it’s a child of the source node.

### 2. **“Concatenated” when there’s no edge label**
- The runner already stores mode for every incoming edge in `buildInputWithVariables` (inject or concatenate), including edges with an empty variable name (no text on the arrow). Those get `"concatenate"` and are passed to `setEdgeModes(canvasKey, edgeModes)`.
- The bug was only in placement: with path-by-index we sometimes had no matching group (e.g. different DOM order) or attached to the wrong path. Now we only need `fromEl`/`toEl` for that edge, so every edge that has a mode in state (including no-label concatenated) gets a label in the right place.

### 3. **Less “cut off in front”**
- Placement no longer uses `translate(-50%, 0)`, which was pulling the label left and could get clipped.
- We use `transform: translate(0, 0)` and set `left` to the midpoint (in fromEl-relative coordinates), so the **left edge of the label** is at the midpoint and the text goes to the right. That avoids the left side being clipped when the node (or parent) clips overflow.

**Code changes:**
- **canvasNodeLabels.ts**: Removed path/foreignObject logic and `getEdgeGroupsInOrder` / `getPathMidpoint`. Restored `getElCenter`, and in `syncCanvasEdgeModeLabels` we again use fromEl/toEl, midpoint relative to fromEl, and append the label div to fromEl with `translate(0, 0)` and `Y_OFFSET_BELOW = 10`. Clear only removes `.ztb-edge-mode-label` (no more foreignObject class).
- **Runner**: Unchanged; it already records concatenate for no-label edges.

The previous debug logs were only in the removed path-based branch, so there is no instrumentation left in the current code path. After reloading the plugin you should see: (1) status labels on the correct edges, (2) “(concatenated)” on arrows with no text, and (3) less or no clipping on the front of the label.

---

Summary of what changed:

**Why it was off**  
Labels were placed at the **geometric midpoint between the two node centers** (straight line). The drawn edge is a **curved path** (e.g. from bottom of one node to top of the other), so that straight-line midpoint is often closer to the start node and doesn’t sit on the arrow.

**What we do now**  
1. **Find the path for this edge**  
   We still use this edge’s `fromNode`/`toNode` to get `fromEl` and `toEl`. We compute the viewport midpoint between those two nodes, then among all `path.canvas-display-path` elements we pick the one whose **path midpoint** (from `getPointAtLength(totalLength/2)`) is **closest** to that viewport point. That ties the path to the correct edge without relying on DOM order.

2. **Position at the arrow’s midpoint**  
   For that path we get the midpoint in **viewport** coordinates using the path’s `getPointAtLength(len/2)` and the SVG’s `getScreenCTM()`. We then express that point as an offset from the **source node** (`fromRect`) and set the label’s `left`/`top` so it sits at that arrow midpoint.

3. **Keep the label on the right edge and moving with the canvas**  
   The label is still appended to **fromEl**, so it stays on the correct edge and moves correctly when you pan/zoom. We only use the path to compute **where** on that edge to draw the label (middle of the arrow).

**Code changes**  
- **`getPathMidpointViewport(pathEl)`** – path midpoint in SVG space, transformed to viewport via the SVG’s `getScreenCTM()`.  
- **`findPathForEdge(containerEl, targetViewportX, targetViewportY)`** – among all `path.canvas-display-path` elements, returns the one whose path midpoint is closest to the given viewport point.  
- In **`syncCanvasEdgeModeLabels`**: we still resolve `fromEl`/`toEl` for the edge, compute the target viewport point (node midpoint), call `findPathForEdge` to get that edge’s path, then use `getPathMidpointViewport(path)` for positioning. If no path is found we fall back to the node midpoint. The label is still appended to `fromEl` with the new `leftPx`/`topPx`.

After rebuilding/reloading, the status labels should sit in the **middle of the arrow** instead of biased toward the start node.

---

_**User**_

No, depending on how zoomed in I am, the labels move about. 

Can you give me 5 alternative solutions for how I can get the position of the status labels to sit in the middle of the curved arrow, and stay in the correct place as I move about the canvas panning and zooming. 

---

_**Agent (model default, mode Agent)**_


The labels move with zoom because we store a **viewport pixel offset** from the source node at sync time. When you zoom, that same offset no longer matches the path midpoint in viewport, so the label drifts.

Here are **5 ways** to keep the status label at the middle of the curved arrow and stable under pan/zoom:

---

**1. Put the label in SVG (foreignObject in the edge’s `<g>`)**

- Find the path for this edge (e.g. with your existing `findPathForEdge`).
- Get the path midpoint in **SVG coordinates**: `path.getPointAtLength(path.getTotalLength() / 2)` (no `getScreenCTM()`).
- Create an SVG `<foreignObject>` with `x`, `y` set to that midpoint (and a small vertical offset), append it to the **same `<g>`** as the path.
- The label then lives in the same coordinate system as the arrow, so it scales and moves with the canvas. To avoid clipping: e.g. set `x = mid.x` (no centering) so the label starts at the midpoint and flows right, and use a width that fits the text.

**2. Reposition on every canvas transform (observe pan/zoom)**

- Keep labels as HTML divs on the source node (or a single overlay).
- Observe the canvas container for transform/scroll changes (e.g. `MutationObserver` on `style`, or `scroll`/`resize`, or Obsidian’s canvas events if they expose them).
- On change, re-run the same logic: path midpoint in **current** viewport → offset from source node → set each label’s `left`/`top`. Pan/zoom updates are applied as the user moves, so the label stays on the arrow.

**3. Same transform as the canvas (overlay in “canvas space”)**

- Get the canvas’s current transform (e.g. from the `.canvas` div’s `style.transform` or the view’s internal state).
- Add a **single** overlay element (sibling to the canvas content) and apply the **same** transform to it.
- Position label divs inside that overlay using **canvas-space** coordinates (e.g. path midpoint in SVG coords, or a coordinate system that matches the canvas). When the canvas pans/zooms, the overlay’s transform is updated the same way, so labels stay aligned with the arrows.

**4. foreignObject in SVG with clipping avoided**

- Same as (1): foreignObject in the edge’s `<g>`, position with path midpoint in SVG coords.
- Avoid clipping by: (a) not using `translate(-50%)` so the FO doesn’t extend left of the path; (b) setting the FO’s `x` to the path midpoint and giving it enough `width`/`height`; (c) if needed, ensuring the SVG/group doesn’t clip (e.g. `overflow: visible` where possible). No viewport math after the first placement, so position is stable under pan/zoom.

**5. Frequent resync (timer) while canvas is active**

- Don’t track transform; instead call your existing sync (or a “reposition only” variant) on a short interval (e.g. 100–200 ms) whenever the canvas view is active.
- Each run: for each edge, path midpoint in **current** viewport → offset from source node → update label `left`/`top`. Labels stay in the middle of the arrow and correct under pan/zoom at the cost of more CPU; no need to touch SVG or observe the canvas transform.

---

**Summary**

| Option | Idea | Pan/zoom stable? | Complexity |
|--------|------|------------------|------------|
| 1 | foreignObject in edge `<g>`, SVG coords | Yes (same coords as path) | Medium |
| 2 | Observe transform, recompute viewport offset | Yes | Medium (need to detect transform) |
| 3 | Overlay with same transform as canvas | Yes | Higher (need transform + overlay) |
| 4 | Same as 1, with careful FO placement to avoid clip | Yes | Medium |
| 5 | Timer-based resync of label positions | Yes | Low |

**Recommendation:** Option 1 (or 4) is usually best: one placement in SVG coordinates, no drift with zoom, and the correct edge is still chosen by your existing “closest path to this edge’s nodes” logic. If you tell me which option you prefer (1–5), I can outline the exact code changes next.

---

_**User**_

Option 4. 

---

_**Agent (model default, mode Agent)**_


Implementing Option 4: placing the label as a foreignObject in the edge's `<g>` using path midpoint in SVG coordinates, with placement chosen to avoid clipping.

Summary of what was implemented for **Option 4**:

### 1. **Correct edge**
- Still using **findPathForEdge(containerEl, targetViewportX, targetViewportY)** so the path is the one whose viewport midpoint is closest to the edge’s node midpoint. That keeps the label on the right arrow.

### 2. **foreignObject in the edge’s `<g>`**
- For that path we take **pathEl.closest("g")** and append a **foreignObject** to that `<g>`, so the label lives in the same SVG group as the arrow and moves with the canvas.

### 3. **Position in SVG coordinates (stable under pan/zoom)**
- **getPathMidpointSvg(pathEl)** returns the path midpoint in **SVG coordinates** via `getPointAtLength(totalLength/2)` (no screen CTM).
- We set the foreignObject’s **x** and **y** to that midpoint (with **y + 12** so it sits just below the path). Because this is in the same coordinate system as the path, the label stays on the arrow when you pan or zoom.

### 4. **Avoiding clipping**
- **x = mid.x** (no centering): the FO’s left edge is at the path midpoint, so the label extends to the right and we avoid left-side clipping.
- **FO size**: width 110, height 28 so “(injected)” / “(concatenated)” fit inside.
- No `translate(-50%)` on the inner div; the content starts at (0,0) inside the FO.

### 5. **Clear**
- **clearCanvasEdgeModeLabels** removes both **.ztb-edge-mode-foreign** (the foreignObjects) and any legacy **.ztb-edge-mode-label** nodes.

If a path isn’t found for an edge (e.g. canvas not fully rendered), we skip that edge and don’t add a label. After rebuild/reload, labels should sit in the middle of the curved arrow and stay fixed relative to the arrow while panning and zooming.

Summary of changes:

### 1. **Bigger label when running**
- **CSS**: `.ztb-edge-mode-label[data-ztb-edge-state="running"]` now uses `font-size: 0.85em` (up from the default `0.7em`) so the “running” status is slightly larger.

### 2. **Center align**
- **Position**: foreignObject is centered on the path midpoint with `x = mid.x - FO_WIDTH / 2` (was `x = mid.x`).
- **CSS**: `.ztb-edge-mode-label` has `justify-content: center` so the content is centered inside the FO.

### 3. **Dot only when waiting for output**
- **Logic**: The orange dot (`.ztb-edge-mode-icon`) is only created when `state === "running"`. For `"inject"` and `"concatenate"` we only add the text “(injected)” or “(concatenated)”.
- **CSS**: Removed icon styling for inject/concatenate so only running state uses the dot.

### 4. **Output edge label smaller / grayed**
- **Logic**: After the main loop we find the path for each **output** edge (run node → green node) and add the class `ztb-output-edge` to its SVG `<g>`. That class is cleared in `clearCanvasEdgeModeLabels`.
- **CSS**:
  - `.ztb-output-edge text`: `font-size: 0.8em`, `fill: var(--text-faint)` for SVG text labels.
  - `.ztb-output-edge foreignObject` and `.ztb-output-edge foreignObject *`: `font-size: 0.8em` and `color: var(--text-faint)` for HTML labels in a foreignObject.

So: running status is slightly bigger and centered; the dot appears only while waiting; (injected)/(concatenated) have no dot; and the “output” edge label is smaller and grayed.

Summary of what was wrong and what was changed:

**Cause:** The foreignObject was positioned with `x = mid.x - FO_WIDTH/2` to center it. In Obsidian’s canvas, path midpoints are in SVG coordinates that are often **negative** (e.g. around -200). So the FO was placed at about -255, which put it outside the visible/clipped area of the SVG, so the labels disappeared.

**Change:** The FO is positioned again with **`x = mid.x`** (left edge of the FO at the path midpoint). It no longer uses centering that can push it into negative coordinates. The label content is still centered inside the FO with `justify-content: center`, so the text stays roughly centered in the 110px-wide box starting at the path midpoint.

**File updated:** `src/canvas/canvasNodeLabels.ts` — the FO’s `x` is set back to `mid.x` and a short comment was added explaining why centering is not used.

After rebuilding and reloading the plugin, the running status and edge labels should show again.  

Note: The current build is failing on existing TypeScript errors in `src/engine/runner.ts` (e.g. argument count and type mismatches). Those are separate from this fix. If you want, we can go through and fix those next.

---


Summary of changes:

### 1. **Native SVG labels (same scaling as Obsidian)**
- Edge status is no longer a `foreignObject` with HTML. It’s now an SVG `<g>` that contains:
  - **Running:** a `<circle>` (dot) plus a `<text>` for "…"
  - **Inject / concatenate:** a single `<text>` for "(injected)" or "(concatenated)"
- Font size is set in SVG user units (`font-size="11"`, `13` when running), so the label scales with the canvas zoom like Obsidian’s edge labels.

### 2. **Stacking above the edge label border**
- The label `<g>` has `style="z-index: 100; isolation: isolate;"` so it draws above the default edge label and its border when zoomed out.
- Clear logic now removes elements with class `ztb-edge-mode-svg-label` (and still clears the old foreignObject/label classes).

### 3. **Styling**
- CSS targets the new SVG structure: `.ztb-edge-mode-svg-label[data-ztb-edge-state="..."] text` and `.ztb-edge-mode-svg-label ... .ztb-edge-mode-icon` (the circle) for fill color and the running pulse animation.
- Legacy HTML label rules are kept for any other use.

### 4. **Layout**
- The `<g>` uses `transform="translate(mid.x, mid.y + 12)"` so the label stays at the path midpoint.
- Running: dot at `(DOT_R+1, FONT_SIZE*0.45)`, text at `(textX, FONT_SIZE*0.35)` with `text-anchor="start"` and `dominant-baseline="central"`.
- Running state uses a slightly larger font (`FONT_SIZE_RUNNING = 13`).

Result: the status label scales with zoom like Obsidian’s edge labels and stays visible above the edge label border at all zoom levels.

---

_**User**_

The running edge status indicators are too difficult to see when I have zoomed out. Please make them a great deal bigger.

---

_**Agent (model default, mode Agent)**_

Summary of changes:

- **Running text:** `FONT_SIZE_RUNNING` increased from 13 to **20** so the "…" is much larger when zoomed out.
- **Running dot:** Added `DOT_R_RUNNING = 5` (replacing the previous 2.5 for running). The running indicator now uses this larger radius so the dot stays visible at distance.
- **Layout:** Running state uses `fontSize` and `DOT_R_RUNNING` for circle position and text so the bigger dot and text stay aligned.

Running indicators (dot + "…") should now be clearly visible when zoomed out; inject/concatenate labels are unchanged at 11px.
